data.title: Historical Events in 1964
data.meta_description: Historical events from year 1964. Learn about 622 famous, scandalous and important events that happened in 1964 or search by date or keyword.
data.text:
Events 1 - 200 of 622

"Top of the Pops"

"Top of the Pops", British pop music television program premieres; acts performing include Dusty Springfield; The Rolling Stones; Dave Clark Five: The Hollies; Swinging Blue; and The Beatles

Jan 1 Federation of Rhodesia & Nyasaland dissolved

Jan 1 KNMT TV channel 12 in Walker, MN (CBS) begins broadcasting

Jan 1 KTVS TV channel 3 in Sterling, CO (CBS) begins broadcasting

Kwame Nkrumah

Failed assassination attempt on President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana

Beatle Mania

Jack Paar shows a clip of the Beatles singing "She Loves You", and says he understands that science was working on a cure for the Beatlemania phenomenon

AFL Championship, Balboa Stadium, San Diego: San Diego Chargers beat Boston Patriots, 51-10; Chargers RB Keith Lincoln rushes for 206 yards, 2 TDs

Pope in Jordan and Israel

Pope Paul VI visits Jordan & Israel

Charlie Finlay announces he wants to move KC A's to Louisville

Jan 6 Rolling Stones' 1st tour of England as headline act: The Ronettes and The Swinging Blue Jeans open for them

Bahamas becomes self-governing

Jan 7 Dick Weber rolls highest bowling game in air (Boeing 707)

"War on Poverty"

President Lyndon B. Johnson declares "War on Poverty"

Anti-US rioting broke out in Panama Canal Zone

Battles between Muslims & Hindus in Calcutta

Jan 10 Panama severs diplomatic relations with US

Jan 10 US version of "That Was The Week That Was" premieres

Jan 10 Vee-Jay Records releases "Introducing the Beatles", the 1st Beatles album released in the US

First government report by US Surgeon General Luther Terry warning that smoking may be hazardous

Jan 11 Panama ends diplomatic relations with US

Jan 11 The Beatles single "I Want to Hold Your Hand" reaches #80 in US (Cashbox)

Revolution overthrows Sultan of Zanzibar, 1 month after independence

Hindu-Muslim rioting breaks out in the Indian city of Calcutta - now Kolkata - resulting in the deaths of more than 100 people.

Future Pope Made Archbishop

John Paul II [Karol Wojtyla] becomes archbishop of Kraków

Bapu Nadkarni 32-27-5-0 v England, 21 maiden overs in a row

Jacqueline Kennedy Appearance

Jacqueline Kennedy's 1st public appearance (TV) since US President JFK's assassination

MLB executives vote to hold a free agent amateur draft, officially known as Major League Baseball First-Year Player Draft in NYC

Willie Mays Highest Paid

San Francisco Giants make champion outfielder Willie Mays the highest-paid player in baseball when they sign him to a new $105,000 per season contract

Jan 15 Teamsters negotiate 1st national labor contract

AL owners vote 9-1 against Charlie Finley moving KC A's to Louisville

Plans for World Trade Center announced (NYC)

Jan 18 The Beatles make their first appearance on US Billboard Chart with single "I Want to Hold Your Hand" at #45

KFME TV channel 13 in Fargo, North Dakota (PBS) begins broadcasting

Capitol Records releases "Meet The Beatles" album by the Beatles, in US

Carl Rowan named director of US Information Agency

Kenneth Kaunda becomes the first President of Northern Rhodesia (Zambia)

Jan 22 World's largest cheese (15,723 kg) manufactured in Wisconsin for New York's World Fair

24th Amendment to the United States Constitution ratified, barring poll tax in federal elections

After the Fall

Arthur Miller's play "After the Fall" premieres in NYC

24th Amendment to the US Constitution "The Elimination of Poll Taxes" goes into effect, removing states ability to deny voting rights due to failure to pay taxes

Jan 24 CBS purchases 1964 and 1965 NFL TV rights for $28.2 million

Jan 24 Dutch comic strip "Eric de Noorman" by Hans G. Kresse ends

Echo 2, US communications satellite launched

Jan 25 Nike athletics company founded in Oregon as Blue Ribbon Sports by University of Oregon track athlete Phil Knight and his coach, Bill Bowerman [1]

Jan 25 The Beatles get their first US #1, "I Want to Hold your Hand" (Cashbox)

Australian cricketers Eddie Barlow and Graeme Pollock combine for a 341 stand at Adelaide Oval

Jan 27 US Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine announces her bid for Republican presidential nomination

"Dr Strangelove"

"Dr Strangelove", directed by Stanley Kubrick and starring Peter Sellers and George C. Scott, premieres

Jan 29 IX Winter Olympic Games open in Innsbruck, Austria

Jan 29 Most lopsided high-school basketball score 211-29 (Louisiana)

Jan 29 NBC purchases AFL 5 year (1965-69) TV rights for $36 million

Jan 29 The Beatles record in German language versions of their hits "Komm, Gib Mir Deine Hand" ("I Want to Hold Your Hand") and "Sie Liebt Dich" (She Loves You") at EMI's Pathé Marconi Studios in Paris, France

Jan 29 Unmanned Apollo 1 Saturn launcher test attains Earth orbit

Military coup of Gen Nguyen Khanh in South Vietnam

Jan 30 Ranger 6 launched; makes perfect flight to Moon, but cameras fail

A rigged constitutional referendum in Ghana sees 99.91% vote in favor, turning the country into a one-party state and making Kwame Nkrumah president for life

Afobaka Dam is completed on the Suriname River

Feb 1 French sisters Christine Goitschel (gold) and Marielle Goitschel (silver) become first female siblings to win Olympic gold and silver in the same event when they dominate the slalom in Innsbruck

Feb 1 Indiana Governor Mathew Walsh tries to ban "Louie Louie" for obscenity

Feb 1 The Beatles' 1st #1 hit "I Want to Hold Your Hand," topped the Hot 100, stays #1 for 7 weeks before being replaced by "She Loves You", also by The Beatles

Baseball Hall of Fame

Elected to Baseball Hall of Fame - Red Faber, Burleigh Grimes, Tim Keefe, Heinie Manush, John Montgomery Ward, & Miller Huggins

Feb 2 GI Joe, debuts as a popular American boy's toy

Feb 2 Sjoukje Dijkstra (Netherlands) wins Olympic gold for figure skating

"Meet the Beatles" album goes Gold

Feb 3 Black & Puerto Rican students boycott NYC public schools

Feb 3 French sisters Marielle Goitschel (gold) and Christine Goitschel (silver) repeat (in reverse order) their top-2 finish in the slalom 2 days earlier, in the giant slalom at the Innsbruck Winter Olympics

FAA begins 6 month test of reactions to sonic booms over Oklahoma City

Latest Wonder of the World

France & Great-Britain sign accord over building channel tunnel

Feb 6 WCIU TV channel 26 in Chicago, IL (IND) begins broadcasting

Baskin-Robbins introduces Beatle Nut ice cream

Feb 7 Beatles land at New York's JFK airport, for 1st US tour

Sessions' 5th Symphony

Roger Sessions' 5th Symphony premieres in Philadelphia with Eugene Ormandy conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra

Royal Hunt of the Sun

Peter Shaffer's musical "Royal Hunt of the Sun" premieres in London

Feb 8 US Rep Martha Griffiths address gets civil rights protection for women being added to the 1964 Civil Rights Act

Beatles on Ed Sullivan Show

1st appearance of the Beatles on "The Ed Sullivan Show", live from New York; broadcast draws 73.7 million television viewers

Feb 9 G.I. Joe “action figure” introduced at the American International Toy Fair in New York

Feb 9 Hanumant Singh scores 105 India v England on debut at Delhi

Feb 9 IX Winter Olympic Games close in Innsbruck, Austria

Feb 9 NYC news anchor Jim Jenson's 1st appearance on WCBS-TV

Australian destroyer HMAS Voyager sinks after colliding with aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne, killing 82

Feb 10 WBGU TV channel 27 in Bowling Green, OH (PBS) begins broadcasting

Beatles 1st live appearance in US, at the Washington Coliseum in Washington, D.C.

Feb 11 Greek & Turks begin fighting in Limassol, Cyprus

Feb 11 Taiwan drops diplomatic relations with France

Beatles 1st NYC concerts, two shows at Carnegie Hall

Cricket History

End of Richie Benaud's 63-Test cricket career in drawn 5th Test v South Africa in Sydney

Feb 12 Fighting breaks out between Turks and Greeks over dispute islands in Cyprus and 16 are killed; the UN responds the following month by sending a peacekeeping force

A World Without Love

British pop music duo Peter & Gordon release single "A World Without Love" (written by Paul McCartney, credited to Lennon-McCartney)

Beatles' "Meet the Beatles!" album goes #1 & stays #1 for 11 weeks

College Basketball

Bill Bradley scores 51 points for Princeton

Music Concert

The Beatles' 2nd appearance on "The Ed Sullivan Show", live from Deauville Hotel in Miami, Florida; broadcast draws about 70 million television viewers

101st member elected to Baseball Hall of Fame, Chicago White Sox shortstop Luke Appling

Feb 17 US House of Representatives accept Law on the civil rights

Feb 17 US Supreme Court rules - 1 man 1 vote (Westberry v Sanders)

Feb 17 WMEM TV channel 10 in Presque Isle, ME (PBS) begins broadcasting

Muriel Resnik's "Any Wednesday" premieres in NYC

Feb 18 Papandreou government takes power in Greece

UK flies ½ ton of Beatles wigs to the US

UK flies 24,000 rolls of Beatles wallpaper to US

Beatles arrive back in England after their 1st US visit

Daytona 500

6th Daytona 500: Race winner Richard Petty leads for record 184 of the 200 laps

Feb 23 Charlie Finley signs a 4 year lease to keep MLB A's in Kansas City

Feb 23 The Beatles' 3rd appearance on "The Ed Sullivan Show", featuring 3 performances taped on February 9, prior to their live debut

"My Heart Skips a Beat" single released by Buck Owens (Billboard No. 1 U.S. Hot Country Singles, 1964)

Austrian chancellor Alfons Gorbach resigns

Ali vs Liston

Muhammad Ali [Cassius Clay] wins his first world heavyweight boxing title when Sonny Liston fails to come out for round 7 at the Convention Center, Miami Beach

The government of Italy asks for help to keep the Leaning Tower of Pisa from toppling over.

World Record

Australian swimmer Dawn Fraser records the fastest 100m freestyle of her brilliant career; smashes her own world record 58.9s in Sydney; goes on to win her 3rd straight gold in the event at the Tokyo Olympics

Sports History

Cincinnati's Jerry Lucas and Oscar Robertson combine for a rare 40-40 performance as the Royals beat host Philadelphia 76ers, 117-114; NBA MVP Robertson has 43 points; Rookie of the Year Lucas, 40 rebounds

Feb 29 LBJ reveals the US has secretly developed the Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird, an advanced, long‐range high-speed and high-altitude reconnaissance airplane [1]

Feb 29 NC high school basketball teams play to 56-54 score in 13 overtime

Music History

Beatles begin filming "A Hard Day's Night", George Harrison meets future wife Pattie Boyd

Teamsters union leader Jimmy Hoffa convicted of jury tampering

Atlanta Mayor Ivan Allen Jr, announces a baseball team is moving there

Mar 5 Emergency crisis proclaimed in Ceylon due to social unrest

Boxing legend Cassius Clay joins the Nation of Islam and changes his name to "Muhammad Ali", calling his former title a "slave name"

Mar 6 Constantine succeeds Paul I as king of Greece

Mar 6 Tom O'Hara runs world record mile (3:56.4)

Event of Interest

Malcolm X resigns from the Nation of Islam

1st Ford Mustang produced

Mar 9 Creighton University's Paul Silas grabs Midwest record 27 rebounds against Oklahoma State

Mar 9 Supreme Court issues NY Times vs Sullivan decision: public officials must prove malice to claim libel and recover damages

Simon and Garfunkel record the first version of "The Sound of Silence" at Columbia Studios in New York City

Mar 10 US reconnaissance plane shot down over East Germany

Film & TV History

Gene Roddenberry brings together a 16-page pitch for the original Star Trek series

Grammy Awards

6th Grammy Awards: Days of Wine & Roses, Barbra Streisand wins 2

Mar 12 S. N. Behrman's play "But for Whom Charlie" premieres in NYC

Mar 12 Union leader Jimmy Hoffa sentenced to 8 years

Mar 12 WKAB TV channel 32 in Montgomery, AL (ABC) begins broadcasting

Turkey threatens Cyprus with armed attack

Murder of Interest

Dallas, Texas; Jack Ruby sentenced to death for Lee Harvey Oswald's murder

USSR performs nuclear test at the Semipalatinsk Test Site in northeast Kazakhstan

KCOY TV channel 12 in Santa Maria, California (CBS) begins broadcasting

Mar 16 LBJ asks Congress to pass Economic Opportunity Act as part of his War on Poverty

Mar 16 Paul Hornung & Alex Karras reinstated in NFL after 1 year suspension

Film & TV History

Sean Connery's 1st day of shooting on James Bond film "Goldfinger"

ESRO established, European Space Research Organization

Beatles' single "She Loves You" goes #1 in the US & stays #1 for 2 weeks

Barbra Streisand appears on the cover of NY Times Magazine section

Sports History

LPGA Western Open Women's Golf, Scenic Hills CC: Carol Mann her 1st of 2 major titles by 2 shots from Ruth Jessen and Judy Kimball

In His Own Write

"In His Own Write", a book of short stories, poems and drawings by John Lennon is published

Mar 23 UNCTAD 1 world conference opens in Geneva

Kennedy half-dollar issued

Event of Interest

Britain sets memorial for the late President John F. Kennedy

Mar 25 Egypt ends state of siege (1952-64)

1st true Pirate Radio station, Radio Caroline (England)

Mar 27 Great Train Robbers sentenced to a total of 307 years behind bars

Mar 27 The Great Alaska Earthquake (9.2 magnitude) and resulting tsunami kill 139 people in the largest US earthquake and second largest ever recorded

Mar 27 UN troops arrive in Cyprus

1st pirate radio station near England (Radio Caroline)

Mar 28 Discovery of Epstein-Barr virus, the first human tumor virus, identified by pathologists English Anthony Epstein and Yvonne Barr published in "Lancet" [1]

Music History

Madame Tussauds Wax Museum in London unveils figures of The Beatles; they later appear on the Sgt. Pepper album cover

Event of Interest

Astronaut John Glenn withdraws from Ohio senate race

10°F lowest temperature ever recorded in Cleveland in April

Apr 1 John Lennon is reunited with his father Freddie after 17 years

Apr 1 Military coup in Brazil by General Castello Branco ousts President João Goulart

Apr 1 Robert Lowell's "Benito Cereno" premieres in NYC

USSR launches Zond 1 to Venus; no data returned

Beatles hold top 6 spots on Sydney Australia record charts

Apr 3 US & Panama agree to resume diplomatic relations

Beatles' "Can't Buy Me Love" single goes #1 & stays #1 for 5 weeks

Apr 4 Deposed President João Goulart leaves Brazil under threat of arrest, moves into life of exile in Uruguay, and later Argentina

1st driverless trains run on London Underground

Egypt & Belgium restore diplomatic relations

IBM announces the System/360 mainframe computer

Unmanned Gemini 1 launched

Demolition begins in Upper Manhattan, New York City on Polo Grounds sports stadium (home to MLB Giants, 1891-1957, Mets, 1962-63, and NFL Jets, 1960-63) to clear way for housing project

Apr 10 Iranian motor launch catches fire & sinks killing 113 (Persian Gulf)

Academy Awards

36th Academy Awards: "Tom Jones" (Best Film), Patricia Neal (Hud) and Sidney Poitier (Lilies Of The Field) win; Poitier first Black actor in a leading role to win a competitive Oscar

Apr 13 Ian Smith becomes Prime Minister of Rhodesia

Apr 13 New Zealander Colin Bosher shears a record 565 sheep in 1 work day

Sports History

LA Dodgers' future Baseball Hall of Fame pitcher Sandy Koufax throws his 9th complete game without allowing a walk in 4-0 Opening Day win over St. Louis Cardinals

Chesapeake Bay Bridge opens (world's longest)

9 men sentenced 25-30 years for Britain's 1963 "Great Train Robbery"

1st game at Shea Stadium, NY Mets lose to Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3

Apr 17 Ford Mustang formally introduced ($2,368 base)

Apr 17 Jerrie Mock becomes 1st woman to fly solo around the world

Artisans strike in Belgium ends

Apr 18 LA Dodgers pitcher Sandy Koufax strikes out the side on 9 pitches, for major league best third time in his career

Rightist coup in Laos, Suvanna Phuma remains premier

Montezuma

Roger Sessions' opera "Montezuma" premieres in West Berlin, Germany

86% of black students boycott Cleveland schools

Pirates & Cubs combine for 9 HRs, Pirates win 8-5

World's Fair at Flushing Meadow, Corona Park, NY opens

Houston Colt 45s Ken Johnson becomes 1st major league pitcher to lose a 9 inning no-hitter, Reds win 1-0

Apr 23 New York State Theater opens

Gene Roddenberry registers his Star Trek series with the Writers Guild of America

Apr 24 Mexico becomes a signatory to the Buenos Aires copyright treaty

Apr 25 11th National Film Awards (India): "Shehar Aur Sapna" wins the Golden Lotus

Apr 25 Stanley Cup Final, Maple Leaf Gardens, Toronto, ON: 3-peat for the Toronto Maple Leafs with a 4-0 Game 7 win over Detroit Red Wings for a 4-3 series victory

LPGA Titleholders Championship

LPGA Titleholders Championship Women's Golf, Augusta CC: Marilynn Smith retains title; beats Mickey Wright by 1 stroke

Apr 26 Tanganyika & Zanzibar form The United Republic of Tanganyika & Zanzibar

John Lennon's book of poetry and sketches "In His Own Write" is published in US

Japan joins the OECD

US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

1st BASIC program runs on a computer (Dartmouth)

First ascent of Shishapangma the fourteenth highest mountain in the world and lowest of the Eight-thousanders

May 2 Mad Dog Vachon beats Verne Gagne in Omaha, to become NWA champ

May 2 The Beatles' "The Beatles' Second Album" goes #1 & stays #1 for 5 weeks

Previous

1

2

3

4

Next
